supporting_quotes: In 1963, Brundtland graduated with a medical degree, a cand.med. from the University of Oslo.
She took her master's degree at Harvard University in 1965, as a Master of Public Health.
From 1966 to 1969, she worked as a physician at the Directorate of Health (Helsedirektoratet)
from 1969 she worked as a doctor in Oslo's public school health service.
She was minister for environmental affairs from 1974 to 1979.
Minister of the Environment In office 6 September 1974 – 8 October 1979
Member of the Norwegian Parliament In office 1 October 1977 – 30 September 1997
Brundtland became leader of the Labour Party in 1981 and held the office until resigning in 1992
Leader of the Labour Party In office 1981–1992

roles: first female Prime Minister of Norway
supporting_quotes: She became the first female prime minister of Norway on 4 February 1981, but left office on 14 October 1981
Brundtland became Norway's first female prime minister in 1981.
At 41 years old she was the youngest person to become Prime Minister of Norway.

organizations: World Commission on Environment and Development (Brundtland Commission)
roles: Chair of the World Commission on Environment and Development
supporting_quotes: In 1983, Brundtland was invited by then United Nations Secretary-General Javier Pérez de Cuéllar to establish and chair the World Commission on Environment and Development (WCED), widely referred to as the Brundtland Commission.
The commission, which published its report, Our Common Future, in April 1987
she returned as prime minister on 9 May 1986 and served until 16 October 1989.

The second ministry was from 9 May 1986 until 16 October 1989 and this cabinet became known worldwide for its high proportion of female ministers: nearly half, or eight of the total eighteen ministers, were female.
Indira Gandhi Prize (1988)
She finally returned for her third term on 3 November 1990.
The third ministry was from 3 November 1990 to 25 October 1996.
Brundtland received the 1994 Charlemagne Prize
In 1994, Brundtland was awarded the Charlemagne Prize of the city of Aachen.
After the end of her term as PM, Brundtland was then elected Director-General of the World Health Organization in May 1998.
Director-General of the World Health Organization In office 13 May 1998 – 21 July 2003
Member of the American Philosophical Society (2002)

roles: 'Policy Leader of the Year' award recipient
supporting_quotes: Brundtland was recognized in 2003 by Scientific American as their 'Policy Leader of the Year' for coordinating a rapid worldwide response to stem outbreaks of SARS.

roles: Grand Cross of the Civil Order of Health recipient
supporting_quotes: Grand Cross of the Civil Order of Health (Spain, 2003)

organizations: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD)
supporting_quotes: In 2006 Brundtland was a member of the Panel of Eminent Persons who reviewed the work of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD).
Brundtland is a founding member of The Elders, a group of world leaders originally convened by Nelson Mandela, Graça Machel and Desmond Tutu
Mandela announced the launch of the group on 18 July 2007 in Johannesburg, South Africa.

roles: UN Special Envoy on Climate Change
supporting_quotes: In May 2007, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon named Brundtland, as well as Ricardo Lagos (the former president of Chile), and Han Seung-soo (the former foreign minister of South Korea), to serve as UN Special Envoys for Climate Change.
served as director-general of the World Health Organization and as UN special envoy on Climate Change from 2007 to 2010.
In 2007, Brundtland was working for Pepsi as a consultant.

roles: Thomas Jefferson Foundation Medal in Architecture recipient
supporting_quotes: Thomas Jefferson Foundation Medal in Architecture (2008)
She was appointed Deputy Chair of the group in 2013 and was succeeded in this role by Ban Ki-moon and Graça Machel in 2018.

roles: Prize International Catalonia recipient (shared with Malala Yousafzai)
supporting_quotes: Prize International Catalonia (2013) with Malala Yousafzai

roles: Tang Prize in Sustainable Development recipient
supporting_quotes: Tang Prize in Sustainable Development (2014)
Honorary member of the Norwegian Association for Women's Rights (2016)
In 2019, Brundtland served as co-chair with the WHO Global Preparedness Monitoring Board.
Brundtland returned to politics when she became a candidate to the Oslo City Council for the 2023 local elections. She ultimately won a seat in the council.
Brundtland is a member of the Council of Women World Leaders, an international network of current and former women presidents and prime ministers
Brundtland is also a member of the Club of Madrid, an independent organization of former leaders of democratic states
She is also deputy chair of The Elders and a former vice-president of Socialist International.

organizations: Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters
